translated: Jātaka
The Nine-Part Collection🔽The Vulture Peak
The Seagull Jātaka
“I say that the two seagulls,

original: Duve duve nandamane carante;🔽Kaṁ aṇḍajaṁ aṇḍajā mānusesu,
analyzed: duve duve nandamane carante  kam aṇḍa jam aṇḍa jāḥ mānusesu
translated: wandering around in pairs,
are born from eggs. Which of them is the one born from an egg that people praise? Tell me that.”
“Among humans, they praise the one born from an egg,
the seagull that is born from an egg.
We are considered to have good character among the birds,
we are beautiful and wander in the ocean.”

original: “Kiṁ aṇṇave kāni phalāni bhuñje,🔽Maṁsaṁ kuto khādatha cakkavākā;
analyzed: kim kāni phalāni bhuñje  masam kutas khādatha cakkavākā
translated: “What fruits do you eat in the ocean?🔽Where do you get meat to eat, seagulls?
What is your food, you of perfect proportions?
You have strength and beauty beyond compare.”
“There are no fruits in the ocean, duck.
Where do we get meat to eat, seagulls?
We eat what we find, we are not choosers.
We do not do evil even for the sake of food.”
“I do not like this, seagull,
this association with food in this existence.
It was different in the past,

analyzed: id ca iva me vimati ettha jātā
translated: thus doubt has arisen in me.
I too eat meat and fruits,
and food with salt and oil,
I get the best of flavours to eat,
Having won the battle at the front.
But I do not have a colour like yours,
O ruddy goose.”

analyzed: a suddha bhakkhaḥ asi khaṇa anupātī  kicchena te labbhati annapāna
translated: “You eat what is impure, you are a time-server,🔽You get food and drink with difficulty,
You are not satisfied with the fruits of the tree, O duck,

original: Maṁsāni vā yāni susānamajjhe.🔽Yo sāhasena adhigamma bhoge,
analyzed: masāni vā yāni susāna majjhe  yaḥ sāhasena adhigamma bhoge
translated: Or with the flesh in the middle of the charnel ground.🔽He who, having obtained wealth through violence,
Enjoys it, O duck, as a time-server,
Then his true nature becomes manifest,
And being manifest, he loses his strength and beauty.

analyzed: appam pi ce nibbutim bhuñjatī yadi
translated: Even if he eats little for his satisfaction,
Not through violence, not harming others,

analyzed: balam ca vaṇṇo ca tat assa hoti
translated: Then he has strength and beauty,

analyzed: na hi sabbaḥ āhāra mayena vaṇṇoti
translated: For not all beauty is made of food.”
The Cakkavāka Jātaka is the eighth.
